div.p:
I have to
thank you for a very great deal
of pleasure to my wife & myself
in the opportunity of becoming
acquainted with your brother Sneyd
Edgeworth of whom we saw during
his short stay in town just enough
to make us much regret his departure
and hope for his speedy return. I
am also greatly obliged by your
kind invitation to Edgeworth town
but fear we cannot hope to
avail ourselves of your tempting
offer this year. We expect Sir
W. Scott & Anne here next week
when he will see all his family

together the first time for many
years; for Charles is now living
with us & labouring in the Foreign
office under Lord Dudley's auspices
& Major Walter is at Hampton
Court, whence I write, with his
Regiment. We shall then arrange
our schemes for the Summer
& I think the end of it will be that
Sophia will go to the Coast with
her children (for Johnny poor
fellow is always much strengthened
by a month or two of seabathing
& has I am sorry to say much
occasion for such aid this year)
While Sir Walter, the gallant
Major & I make a little

excursion to Germany. I had thought
of Portugal but the precious Don
Miguel (whom some of the
Cockneys took for the great
Mogul) seems to have put
that out of the question very
effectually. Is there no hope
for yr your coming over this Spring
There will be Scott & Tom Moore
& old Crabbe & I know not
how many more of your
Lion species I hear, and surely
you ought to swell the muster
if possible. Crabbe has another
volume of tales forthcoming
Moore is to bring out his Byroniana
in November & is very busy

collecting materials for the four
winds of heaven. I hope he will
do better than w with
Sheridan he
has at least as delicate and
difficult a task in hand but
he says he has already got so
many letters and diaries that
he expects to have little more
to answer for than the putting
together, despite the unhappy
fire, of an autobiography.
And is there truth in the good
news that a novel from
Miss Edgeworth is to be
one of these treasures of 1828?
I hope so indeed: for with

reverence be it said I have tried
in vain to admire very much
any of the Gentlemen who have
of late years been trying to
occupy the domain which you
first opened & conquered &
where you ought to make still
larger conquests. If it be
true let me take the great liberty
of suggesting that the money -
- value of a good novel must
now be Great indeed when
such writers as have been
suffered to flourish have also
been enabled to get £1000 &
£1500 for Each of their productions

I venture to say that if you will
submit your Ms to Sir Walter
Scott he knows better than any
one else how to deal with the
trade when he has such wares
to vend & that you will be
somewhat surprized surprised with the
result of his Management
Whether w with his own publisher
or w with the arch-puffer Mr
Colburn - which last personage
wd
would give his ears for such
a name as yours to grace
his lists.
There is no news here The King

is very feeble but in good spirits
& is to sit through a levee next
week, having w with difficulty
overcome his repugnance to
making such an exhibition
of his royal frame.
Once more then I hope
wyou will be persuaded to join
Sir W.S. &c &c here this
Spring.
div.closer:
Ever faithfully yours,
J G Lockhart

postscript.p:
Sunday March 23. 1828.
Hampton Court
I am very very sensible to your
kind language about Crofton
Croker's affairs. To tell you the
truth he has been for years
engaged to marry a very
respectable woman & only
his poverty keeps him single
so I was anxious some effort
shd be made for him. I fear
from his bookseller's silly vanity
stuffing the book w writings
of his own, the booby, the thing
has gone down. If anything
can hoist the vessel up again
it will be your kind hand.
1828 Lockhart
